title: 112_hr1120
content:
The Act is titled the "International Travelers Bill of Rights Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "International Travelers Bill of Rights Act of 2011" defines key terms such as site operator, Commission, international travel services, overseas vacation destination, and United States. The term "United States" includes several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 3. Providing information on health and safety risks of overseas vacation destinations. SEC. 3. Providing information on health and safety risks of overseas vacation destinations. A site operator must inform consumers about health and safety risks of overseas vacation destinations on its website, including State Department travel warnings, onsite health services, and medical staff availability. Overseas vacation destinations must have personnel trained in CPR, an automated external defibrillator, and lifeguards for water activities. If health services are not available 24/7, the site operator must inform consumers about health and safety risks. The site operator must clearly display the availability of onsite health and safety services on its website. If these services are not available at an overseas vacation destination, a notice must be displayed warning of potential health and safety risks. SEC. 4. CONSUMER COMPLAINTS.

A site operator must suspend an overseas vacation destination from its website due to consumer complaints about poor medical care, unsafe facilities, or health-related issues. Complaints must be made public on the website, with the option to modify or remove offensive content.

SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT.

Violation of this Act is treated as a violation of FTC rules. The Commission will enforce this Act as if it were part of the Federal Trade Commission Act. Regulations must be issued within 6 months of enactment.
